stream_context.summary: Kaze continues work on the western/cowboy course, focusing on the mole hideout encounter: implementing Monty Mole rock-throwing behavior that aims at Mario, tuning damage/coin drops, and brainstorming a simple “clear the room” boss design. He also reveals he replaced SM64’s original collision with a new custom collision system for stability, discusses which intentional glitches to preserve (e.g., BLJ), and gives a high-level project status (stars 1–2 nearly done; ~80% overall remaining content scoped).
stream_context.significance_reason: Kaze reveals a major engine change—replacing Mario 64’s collision system entirely—and gives concrete project-completion scope (~80% done, with remaining courses/side levels/Bowser level). He also lands on a pragmatic boss solution for the mole hideout and declares stars 1–2 essentially complete pending polish.

findings.summary: Kaze implemented a completely new collision system, explicitly replacing SM64’s original collision because he considers it too unstable/unusable; he demonstrates improved stability in previously “sticky” or broken spots (less getting stuck in bad geometry).
findings.quote: I made a completely new collision system. I said, fuck Mario 64's collision. It is unusable. We have our completely own collision system now. And it's so much more stable.

findings.summary: He articulates a bug/glitch policy: keep glitches that require intentional player effort (e.g., BLJ-like exploits) but remove bugs that can happen accidentally during normal play.
findings.quote: If there's a bug in Mario 64 that you only encounter if you do it on purpose, I'll leave it in the game. But if it can happen on accident, I'll remove it.

findings.summary: For Monty Mole rock throws, he solved the non-predictive aiming problem by computing the correct vertical velocity using a per-frame step sum (gravity -4), so rocks land at Mario’s current position at the time of throw (not leading Mario).
He intentionally avoids predictive projectile targeting; the goal is not to “counter BLJ/speedrun tech,” but to keep behavior readable and fair while still leveraging more stable physics.
findings.quote: No, it shoots exactly where Mario is at. It's not predictive. I don't want this to be predictive.

findings.summary: He notes RAM constraints are still shaping level collision: he temporarily removed collision from a bridge area “for RAM reasons,” implying collision data budget is a practical limiter in this course.

Boss encounter direction shifts from a complex ‘five moles remaining get faster’ concept toward a simpler, clearer encounter: multiple moles pop from randomized holes and the win condition is defeating all of them, with an emphasis on preventing players from picking them off one-by-one at the edges.
He adjusts combat tuning: considers rock damage (initially 2) and later leans toward 1 coin reward per mole death (debating 1 vs 2) to fit pacing/feedback for the encounter.

He discovers and fixes multiple behavior-script issues while implementing the encounter: wrong-side spawns, left-offset aiming, state not resetting causing objects to stop interacting, and coin spawning blocked by SM64’s safety checks until the coin count is set explicitly.

Kaze explains how he interprets feedback: he tries to infer the player’s underlying feeling rather than implementing criticism literally, because critics can overfit to “parameters” instead of the emotion a game evokes.
findings.quote: When I receive a criticism, I try to figure out what the person was feeling that's wrong... I try to look at the underlying feeling.

findings.summary: Project status update: after this course segment, he estimates only three main courses, two side levels, and one Bowser level remain—about “80% of the way there.”
findings.quote: The levels are left to make after this: three more main courses and two side levels and one Bowser level. We're like 80% of the way there.

findings.summary: End-of-stream checkpoint: the mole boss fight is “basically done” pending animations and decoration polish; Kaze says stars 1 and 2 for this area are effectively finished and he plans to move to star 3 (the “Goomba imposter tower”) next.
findings.quote: The boss fight's basically done... then star one and two are done and we need to move on to star three... the Goomba imposter tower.

findings.summary: Zeina is mentioned as not being home today; Kaze flags missing/needed animations as a remaining dependency for making the encounter feel finished (dizzy/death/shake effects after stomps).

Kaze outlines a post-release career plan: alongside releasing Return to Yoshi’s Island, he expects to launch a Kickstarter for an original game and transition focus to that project, ideally hiring other ROM hackers.
findings.quote: Alongside the release of Return to Yoshi's Island I'll probably launch a Kickstarter for my own game... and then hopefully I can hire some other rom hackers to work on it with me.

findings.summary: He recounts an ad/sponsorship conflict: a company that sent a bootleg emulation handheld expected a more conventional promo and possibly a main-channel upload; Kaze ignored their complaints and points out the mismatch between their expectations and normal ad rates.
Lilaa is present in chat; Kaze riffs on Lilaa’s streams/identity and later uses Lilaa as a recurring conversational foil during brainstorming.

Chat ideas (including Lilaa and others) push alternative boss concepts (e.g., power-up-based solutions, harder mechanics). Kaze rejects some (hard hats/tank) to maintain western theming and readability, and settles on random-hole mole popping.

Viewers propose multiple boss variants: survive bullet waves, a star that pops in/out, one mole holding the star, or requiring a specific tool/power-up. Kaze evaluates them mainly on clarity, theming (western), and implementation practicality.
Chat prompts Kaze to show the bridge area and to demonstrate collision stability and BLJ implications, indirectly shaping what development artifacts he surfaces on stream.

key_stories.title: Replacing Mario 64 collision with a custom system
key_stories.summary: While working in the cowboy course, Kaze stops to demonstrate that he has replaced SM64’s collision entirely. He frames the original collision as unusable for their needs and shows the new system handling awkward geometry without sticking.
key_stories.challenge: SM64 collision instability and player getting stuck in broken/complex geometry, limiting level design freedom and overall polish.
key_stories.process: He implemented a new collision system from scratch and tested it live in problematic areas to verify stability; he acknowledges ceilings may still need work.
key_stories.outcome: Significantly improved movement stability in rough geometry; BLJ behavior changes as a side effect, prompting a design stance on which glitches to preserve.
key_stories.key_quote: We have our completely own collision system now. And it's so much more stable.

key_stories.title: Making Monty Mole rocks reliably hit Mario without predictive aiming
key_stories.summary: Kaze needs moles to throw rocks that land where Mario is, but early attempts spawn on the wrong side, don’t travel far enough, or aim offset. He wrestles with the physics math, then derives the per-frame sum approach and gets consistent throws.
key_stories.challenge: Compute initial Y velocity under fixed gravity (-4) over a known number of frames/distance so the projectile reaches Mario’s height at the target point; avoid “fake” math while keeping behavior fair.
key_stories.process: He abandons unreliable LLM output, derives the discrete frame-step sum himself, implements the formula, and fixes axis/ordering bugs that caused left-offset aiming and wrong delta calculations.
key_stories.outcome: Rocks now aim correctly at Mario’s current position; the encounter becomes viable as an introductory mechanic leading into a room-clear boss variant.

key_stories.title: Boss design pivot: from complex ‘five moles’ to a clear room-clear encounter
key_stories.summary: Kaze brainstorms a boss for the mole hideout after building the room, questioning whether multiple moles and many rocks would be visually messy. He decides a simpler fight—moles popping from randomized holes until defeated—is clearer and fits the space.
key_stories.challenge: Create a fun, readable boss that fits a western theme and doesn’t devolve into cluttered projectile spam or confusing mole-state collisions.
key_stories.process: He evaluates several suggestions (waves survival, star pop-in/out, one mole holding a star, tool/power-up gimmicks) and keeps returning to clarity and theme; he adds random-hole logic to prevent easy edge-picking.
key_stories.outcome: “Boss fight basically done” structurally; remaining work is animations, tuning speed/spacing, and decoration polish.

key_stories.title: N64 constraints in 2026: RAM/collision budgets still drive compromises
key_stories.summary: When asked about a bridge area in the cowboy course, Kaze explains collision was removed temporarily due to RAM. Later he comments on how bandwidth/memory constraints shaped N64-era performance and still influence their hack’s technical choices.
key_stories.challenge: Fitting collision and behavior within tight N64 memory/bandwidth constraints while building larger, more complex courses.
key_stories.process: Selective removal/deferral of collision in high-geometry spots; continued optimization and engine refactors (including collision rewrite).
key_stories.outcome: Playable area continues to evolve, but some sections ship with temporary limitations until budgets are rebalanced.

key_stories.title: Sponsor mismatch: the bootleg handheld ad that made a company mad
key_stories.summary: Kaze recounts a sponsorship where a company sent a handheld emulation device and expected a conventional, product-forward ad (and possibly a main-channel upload). He instead made an unconventional, candid ad read and then ignored their complaints.
key_stories.challenge: Misaligned expectations about ad format, placement, and compensation; reputational risk of promoting gray-market hardware.
key_stories.process: Kaze states he set expectations up front, delivered an ad he considered effective, and declined to rework/argue further, noting normal main-channel ad rates are far higher.
key_stories.outcome: Company remained upset; Kaze treats it as a lesson in sponsor fit and pricing rather than a serious legal threat.
